verses.text: So all Israel was registered by genealogies written in the Book of the Kings of Israel. And Judah was taken away into exile in Babylon because of their unfaithfulness.
verses.comment: References Judah's exile as a result of their unfaithfulness as detailed elsewhere.

verses.text: Now the first to live again in their lands, in their cities, were Israelites, priests, Levites, and temple servants.
verses.comment: Lists the groups returning after exile: Israelites, priests, Levites, and temple servants.

verses.text: And in Jerusalem lived some from the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh:
verses.comment: States the main tribes whose people lived in Jerusalem after exile.

verses.text: Uthai the son of Ammihud, son of Omri, son of Imri, son of Bani, from the sons of Perez, son of Judah.
verses.comment: Perez was one of Judah's sons, providing genealogical connection.

verses.text: And from the Shilonites: Asaiah the firstborn, and his sons.
verses.comment: Shilonites descend from Shelah, another son of Judah.

verses.text: From the sons of Zerah: Jeuel and their relatives, six hundred ninety.
verses.comment: Zerah was also a son of Judah.

verses.text: From the sons of Benjamin: Sallu son of Meshullam, son of Hodaviah, son of Hassenuah;
verses.comment: Benjamin also prominent in Jerusalem's population post-exile.

verses.text: Ibneiah son of Jeroham; Elah son of Uzzi, son of Michri; and Meshullam son of Shephatiah, son of Reuel, son of Ibnijah;
verses.comment: Genealogies maintain the post-exilic community’s heritage.

verses.text: and their relatives, according to their generations: nine hundred fifty-six. All these men were heads of families in their fathers' houses.
verses.comment: Adds up the genealogies into a total.

verses.text: From the priests: Jedaiah; Jehoiarib; Jakin;
verses.comment: The main priestly families listed here correspond with Nehemiah.

verses.text: Azariah son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub, the chief officer of God's house.
verses.comment: Azariah is highlighted as the leading official over the temple.

verses.text: And Adaiah son of Jeroham, son of Pashhur, son of Malchijah; Maasai son of Adiel, son of Jahzerah, son of Meshullam, son of Meshillemith, son of Immer;
verses.comment: Adds additional priestly lineages.

verses.text: their relatives, heads of their fathers' houses, one thousand seven hundred sixty–mighty men for the work of the service of God's house.
verses.comment: Lists total number of priestly men ready for temple service.

verses.text: And of the Levites: Shemaiah son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, from the sons of Merari;
verses.comment: Levites listed here come from Merari’s line.

verses.text: Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, and Mattaniah son of Mica, son of Zikri, son of Asaph;
verses.comment: Includes Levites and a descendant of Asaph, the musician.

verses.text: Obadiah son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun; and Berechiah son of Asa, son of Elkanah, who lived in the villages of the Netophathites.
verses.comment: Jeduthun and Asaph both are heads of Levitical singer clans.

verses.text: The gatekeepers: Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives; Shallum was their chief.
verses.comment: Gatekeepers keep order and security at the temple.

verses.text: Previously, they were stationed at the King's Gate to the east. These were the gatekeepers for the camps of the Levites.
verses.comment: The King’s Gate was the prominent eastern entrance.

verses.text: Shallum son of Kore, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah, and his relatives from Korah’s family—for the work of service, keepers of the gate of the tent. Their fathers had kept the entrance to the LORD’s camp.
verses.comment: Descendants of Korah had a legacy of gatekeeping.

verses.text: Phinehas son of Eleazar had been chief over them in earlier times. The LORD was with him.
verses.comment: Phinehas was known for his zeal for God.

verses.text: Zechariah son of Meshelemiah was gatekeeper at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
verses.comment: Gatekeepers guarded the main door to the sanctuary.

verses.text: All those chosen as gatekeepers at the threshold totaled two hundred twelve. They were listed by genealogies in their villages. David and Samuel the seer had appointed them in their trusted positions.
verses.comment: King David and Samuel established this gatekeeper order.

verses.text: So they and their sons guarded the gates of the house of the LORD, that is, the tabernacle.
verses.comment: The sons carried on this tradition of service.

verses.text: Gatekeepers were on the four sides: east, west, north, and south.
verses.comment: Every entrance had designated guards.

verses.text: Their relatives in their villages were assigned to come in rotation for seven days at a time with them.
verses.comment: Relatives assisted and had a share in the temple service.

verses.text: For the four chief gatekeepers, who were Levites, were in charge of the chambers and treasuries of God’s house.
verses.comment: Main gatekeepers also handled the temple’s valuables.

verses.text: They stayed overnight around God's house, because they had responsibility to guard it and to open it every morning.
verses.comment: Required vigilance at all hours.

verses.text: Some of them were in charge of the utensils used in worship. These counted them whenever they brought them in or took them out.
verses.comment: Meticulous record-keeping ensured proper usage.

verses.text: Some of them were in charge of the furniture and all the other sacred objects, as well as the flour, wine, oil, incense, and spices.
verses.comment: Levites handled everything needed for rituals.

verses.text: Some of the sons of the priests prepared the ointment of the spices.
verses.comment: Priests made the sacred anointing oil.

verses.text: Mattithiah, one of the Levites—the firstborn son of Shallum the Korahite—was in charge of making the flat cakes for offering.
verses.comment: Shows specific duties assigned to named Levites.

verses.text: Some of their relatives, from the Kohathites, were responsible for preparing the bread of the Presence every Sabbath.
verses.comment: Bread of the Presence kept permanently before the LORD.

verses.text: These are the singers, heads of the fathers' houses of the Levites, who lived in the chambers of the temple, free from other duties; they were continually engaged in their work day and night.
verses.comment: Musicians focused on praise and worship full-time.

verses.text: These were heads of fathers' houses of the Levites, according to their generations. They lived in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Summarizes Levite leadership in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Jeiel, father of Gibeon, lived in Gibeon. His wife’s name was Maacah.
verses.comment: Begins genealogy of Saul’s family.

verses.text: His firstborn son was Abdon; then Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,
verses.comment: Direct Saul-family genealogy.

verses.text: Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth.
verses.comment: Genealogy continued from previous verse.

verses.text: Mikloth fathered Shimeam. These also lived near their relatives in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Shows family settled together in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Ner fathered Kish; Kish fathered Saul; Saul fathered Jonathan, Malchi-shua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
verses.comment: Trace Saul’s sons, parallel to other genealogy passages.

verses.text: Jonathan fathered Merib-baal, and Merib-baal fathered Micah.
verses.comment: Merib-baal is also called Mephibosheth.

verses.text: The sons of Micah: Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz.
verses.comment: Lists next generation in Saul's family.

verses.text: Ahaz fathered Jarah; Jarah fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri; and Zimri fathered Moza.
verses.comment: Continues Saul’s grandson genealogy.

verses.text: Moza fathered Binea; his son was Rephaiah, his son was Eleasah, his son was Azel.
verses.comment: Multiple generations named.

verses.text: Azel had six sons: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were the sons of Azel.
verses.comment: Ends genealogy with Azel’s six sons.
